text: [[dragonlord dromoka]] being $10+ is a weird thought

text: Why?
Half a [[Grand Abolisher] with flying and life link that can be your commander seems pretty good.
I just remember it being way less than that and never saw the price until now
One of those "how the hell did I miss that" moments
Gotcha.
My friend's Dragonlord Dromoka deck constantly screws me becuase I forgot his ability. "I'll just save this fact or fiction until the end of his turn . . "
Then when I go to cast it I can't

I lost to it this week becuase I had both a Putrefy and Sudden Spoiling in hand and was sure I'd be safe on his turn, and he dropped Dromoka with haste off a Hall of the Bandit Lord and berserked her.
My kruphix deck lost to her for similar reasons.
Yeah...Dromoka is probably the best of the newer Elder dragons
I dunno, that Kolaghan character is pretty sweet...
Umm.... If you're playing against Rats or Apostles.
Right?
[Dragonlord Kolaghan]]
[[Dragonlord Kolaghan]]

text: Yeah, okay, that's the one I was thinking.
My mom actually plays and she pilots [[Dragonlord Ojutai]]. She likes flying, likes drawing cards, loves counterspells, and hates people touching her Commander with their filthy removal spells

text: Ojutai is solid.
Silumgar is pretty sick, too.
If I was helping a kid build a commander deck I'd absolutely have him/her build [[Atarka, World Render]]

attachments.text:
Legendary Creature — Dragon
Flying, trample
Whenever a Dragon you control attacks, it gains double strike until end of turn.
_"Her hunger knows no limit. Left unchecked, she would feast on all of Tarkir." —Yasova Dragonclaw_
*6/4*
attachments.title: Atarka, World Render {5}{R}{G}

text: Ramp colors, easy land base, and even with dollar-bin dragons you can blow people apart
Easy to pilot too, and DARGONS!
Has clear upgrade lines, too. Add a Greater Good, Berserk or Gratuitous Violence down the road, etc.
Red green is a good starting place. I might go with Xenagos, expensive as he is. The rest of his deck can be dirt cheap and still knock out experienced players out of nowhere.
Xenagod is probably better, but if you wanna play dragons Atarka is about as clean and simple as it gets
Way easier to command damage someone too
I'd be impressed if anyone manages to win with commander damage with Xenagod :relaxed:
I like a lot of the dragons they're reprinting for the Ur Drgaon deck. Atarka and such feel good for new players. I wish they'd been as forthcoming with the mana base...
Especially after the 2016 deck's mana bases.
Or even shit like finishing the Talisman cycle in enemy colors, or finishing the Odyssey filters in enemy colors
That doesn't require any testing, and I guarentee they have workable art sitting in a folder somewhere
This doesn't seem the product to finish that cycle, though. They only get ~55 new cards, they want to make thematic stuff instead of completing a cycle most commander players won't know exists
They only get 55 new cards because they choose to though. They could up that to 60 by saying they're upping it to 60 and slap in the signets.

More than that, though, Wizards is a business that thrives off of keeping players in suspense. Most of us thought we were going to get Ally pair commander decks after Meren and Mizzix and all them came out. It's now been two new products without Ally pairs. It causes us to feel like the cycle is unfinished, and eventually demand an ally color commander product, rather than lamely expect one
I kinda get what you're saying, but there's also a finite amount of places to actually make this stuff. We'll never see talismans in standard.
Right, nor should we
Since they're excellent commander cards it seems the best and maybe only spot to actually make them
Why shouldn't we get the talisman's in standard?

I'd love to see them too, frankly. Or a finished Krosan Verge cycle, or the Enemy-pair Skycloud Expanse-style filterland cycle. There's a lot of stuff to finish up. There are just some other higher priority design decisions, and I can understand that. Besides, it creates demand the longer they wait

Except in commander I'm not sure those things really require that much time as to impact things of a higher priority. The templating already exists, and there's zero concerns about strength level for other formats. An intern could literally knock off the Talisman cycle, the filters, Krosan verge, etc in an afternoon probalby with art.
I see what you're saying about increasing demand

But I'm not sure those kind of things sell packs in a way impacted by demand. Mana Drain getting reprinted or Damnation is a demand-building thing more than likely. I have a hard time believing the Talismans are the same thing

<@U3L7A68JC> Colorless ramp kind of steps on green's color pie, philosophically, so that's a piece of it. They can mess with limited environments too, making it too easy to splash other colors. The parallel is signets, which are so good they're included in the Vintage cube. Talismans aren't signets, but there's still a similarity that's too close for R&D's comfort. Wizards has found their safe spot at 3 mana for colorless fixing, like Manalith and the Khans Banner cycle
That argument rings a bit hollow when they introduce cards like [[Aetherworks Marvel]] into standard.

attachments.fallback: Aetherworks Marvel {4} // Legendary Artifact // Whenever a permanent you control is put into a graveyard, you get {E} (an energy counter). // {T}, Pay {E}{E}{E}{E}{E}{E}: Look at the top six cards of your library. You may cast a card from among them without paying its mana cost. Put the rest on the bottom of your library in a random order.
attachments.text:
Legendary Artifact
Whenever a permanent you control is put into a graveyard, you get {E} _(an energy counter)_.
{T}, Pay {E}{E}{E}{E}{E}{E}: Look at the top six cards of your library. You may cast a card from among them without paying its mana cost. Put the rest on the bottom of your library in a random order.
attachments.title: Aetherworks Marvel {4}

text: So it's ok to bypass mana requirements, but efficient fixing is too strong...?
So much of what WotC does now focuses on bypassing mana altogether.

I'm not saying Talismans make people buy packs. I'm just saying it's a low, low priority and it keeps us in suspense the longer they wait. They've trained us to like cycles, so whenever we notice an incomplete cycle, we keep paying attention to the game until its finished. That's why we only got Ally-pair Cycling lands in Amonkhet, and not the full set of 10. They only recently finished the Fast Lands cycle in Kaladesh, a land cycle from way back in Scars of Mirrodin. That's a gap of like 6 years before they completed that cycle. They like keeping us in suspense. We keep buying packs as long as we're paying attention, and we're paying attention when our brains notice asymmetry.

(And at henry: Talismans = turn 3 Aetherworks Marvel is basically the fear. They don't want that. Aetherworks was a mistake but 2 mana artifact ramp in the same set only would have compounded that mistake)
Marvel was simply an example vs. the all-encompassing issue.
Efficient fixing is a thing all decks could use, whereas Marvel was its own specific deck, so there is a difference
But yeah, cheating costs has always been a dangerous thing
*looks pointedly at Force of Will, Time Spiral, Treasure Cruise, Aetherworks Marvel, and Bloodbraid Elf*
Freaking reserve list buyouts...[[martyr's cry]] is now $10 and I was going to get one for a [[taigam, ojutai master]] deck with lab man and [[secure the waste]] effects.
